(Time expired) does not require his ex-partner to even so Question resolved in the negative. much as, to my understanding, look for work Sitting suspended from 7.24 p.m. to or attempt to retrain and become more inde 10 a.m. (Friday) 12154 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 December 1997 Thursday, 4 December 1997 Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Report Debate resumed from 20 October 1997, on motion by Mr Sinclair: That the House take note of the paper. about the report that is now before us, Sharpening the focus: report on a seminar on the Simons committee report. The first is that the ministerial statement which gives the government's response to the Simons report has now been tabled. On 18 November last, on page 10578 of Hansard, the Minister for Foreign Affairs( Mr Downer) responded to the Simons report; consequently the seminar, which was part of the process to determine the direction of Australian aid, is now at another phase. I want to echo the views expressed at the seminar, and earlier on by the minister, by extending to the members of the Simons committee our congratulations on their efforts. The report itself, One clear objective: poverty reduction through sustainable development, is an excellent analysis. It is an analysis that was badly needed because there had not been one since the report prepared by Gordon Jackson 13 years before. It is interesting that there were many areas of contrast between the Gordon Jackson report and the Simons report. We were very fortunate at the seminar, which is actually the focus of this debate today, because we had present each of the members of the committee. It is also worth saying that the members of the aid community were excellent in the way they were prepared to participate in public analysis of the proposals that really embrace not only NGOs and development assistance aid, but also economic aid and the whole range of areas where Australia is involved in helping other countries. It was interesting that at the seminar, as in the minister's statement, there was no questioning of the view that Australia has an ongoing commitment to providing development assistance aid to other countries. The area where there is a problem, and it is one which we cannot ignore, the more so because of the currency-volatility in our area, is in the area of economic aid. At a time when there is reason to look at Australia's economic relationships and when the Development Import Finance Facility, the DIFF, has been suspended, we should look at economic aid and see where we go with that. I hope that in the government's response to the Mortimer report there might be consideration given to an alternative to DIFF. There are various levels of aid. These are issues that emerged at the seminar and emerged in other dialogue about the Simons committee report. One of those aid issues, and it is a difficult one, was put by Mr Wolfensohn, one of the speakers. He was perhaps the most vocal on the issue. He put the point, and it is a point that I accept although I know it is questioned by others, that if you can advance the economic level in a country, if you can advance the number of people who are in the middle class, and if you can provide more job opportunities
title: Delegation Reports Transition Having Only Had Non Racial General

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nehl) Took The Chair At 10.00 A.m.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sinclair (New England) (10.00 A.m.)
theText: There are three things that need to be saidThursday, 4 December 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 12155 for a community, you are not only going to make that community better off economically but going to advance the cause of human rights. Also, if you can advance the economic level in a country you are going to advance the cause of those people examining where they are and what their position is in society, and you are going to help even the issue of freedom of the press. I say that because today, if people are able to afford TV sets and earth stations and so on, that means that they have greater access to information It is important that we do not just dismiss the area of economic' aid. It is a field. I call it economic aid but, in a way, it is assistance to Australian industry. As .one who has been involved for many years in the trade field, I think there is an advantage in our being able to help Australian business people into other countries, not peculiarly because of the profits they make, but because of the job creation that it gives, both in those countries and back in Australia. Carefully tailored, there is purpose in providing financial incentive to Australian business to provide aid abroad. That is the one area where we have not concluded our consideration of the Simons committee report. The Simons committee report essentially gave the emphasis to poverty reduction. The minister in his response has confirmed that that is the government's prime objective. In our report we pointed out that poverty reduction really needs to be interpreted in a very broad way. I do have concerns about the way in which we look at poverty reduction because there are obviously advantages in helping people to help themselves. In its way, that relates to the point I was making a moment ago about economic aid. What we have to do is to encourage people to help themselves. In other words, if you can help people to fish, they are going to be a hell of a lot better off than if you are just going to give them fish. So what we want to do is create a climate where people can not only look after themselves at a subsistence level of agriculture, but where they can transfer from a subsistence level to producing food and fibre at a more sophisticated level so that they have a surplus to sell to generate the cash flows that enable them to improve their own living standards. The same applies to some of the basics. I remain most concerned that in the definition of poverty we do not deny the capacity, for example, to help people put down wells, to improve water supply, to improve sanitation, to provide sewerage. There is a group called the RedR Society, who are a group of engineers who do tremendous work. Having been involved in and looked at their work, I am convinced that, in many ways, the work they do is helping the health of people in developing countries more than many of those who are working directly in the health area. If you can provide access to clear clean water, if you can provide an opportunity that prevents women in many instances walking many kilometres just carrying buckets of water on their heads or their shoulders, it helps those villagers to lift their standard of living. To my mind, poverty alleviation is not just a matter of looking at the monetary terms, at cash flows; it is a matter of looking at lifestyle and providing conditions of life and living which are going to give opportunities to people to live in a better way. So when we are looking at this one clear objective, the title given the Simons report; on poverty reduction we do need to have a very broad definition of poverty reduction. That is one of the recommendations we have produced in our Sharpening the focus report. 12156 MAIN .COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 December 1997 We believe it is essential that you look not just at poverty in the monetary sense, but at ways by which you can improve people's lifestyle. From that, of course, you have to look at the relationship of women in particular in many developing communities. One of the tragedies of so many societies is that women are just not given the educational opportunity. I was reading a paper the other day which had figures from India which showed that while over 70 per cent of the male work force are literate, less than 20 per cent of women in the work force are literate, which is appalling. What we have to do is recognise that in many societies women have been given a less than equal opportunity. I think it is important that we look at the facets of how, in our aid program, we can help towards providing a better opportunity for women and children-of either sex-so that they too can have a better living standard in the future. The minister did produce a very good answer to the Simons report. Obviously the big area of doubt is whether enough money is being provided. It has been an ongoing debate for years. It is not peculiar to overseas aid. I know that in all communities there is a feeling that they want more money for whatever the particular local project might be. I have just been doing some correspondence in my office and most of those letters relate to people who want money for schools, for research, for health, and they want other doctors. There are all sorts of programs we want money for. All of us, as members, are aware with every moment of our working lives that we always have this conflict of where money should be provided. But I do not think people need to underestimate, as I believe some of the rhetoric of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) has, the contribution that foreign aid makes to Australia's well-being. We are not just citizens introspectively looking at ourselves and our own neighbours. We have to playa positive role in the wider world community. As far as I am concerned, it is very important that we maintain adequate funding for Australia's development assistance program. I am pleased to see that the minister has given his commitment to this objective, although the quantum of funds available is not necessarily the amount that he would like. I do not want to go into the details of the aid program other than with respect to PNG. I am particularly concerned at where we are going in PNG, quite apart from present problems associated with Prime Minister Skate. I think we need to understand that PNG does have a unique relationship with Australia. She has been the major recipient of our aid. I believe that the transfer from budget to project aid is the way to go, but there are a lot of ifs and buts still in the manner of admin-stration of the country of PNG. I am worried about law and order and not just in the cures at the police level. I am also worried about the job creation necessary. Young people are returning to the villages. It is no use letting the Rascals of today and tomorrow in Lae and Port Moresby and all these other towns take over the sinews of government. Our aid program needs to be directed sympathetically to providing those people with a chance for the future. I know the minister has identified some of these issues in his statement. He has talked about the relief aid to overcome the famine, which has been appalling. He has also talked about the ongoing assistance that we are providing to PNG. I believe PNG is the appropriate country which should continue to see the major level of Australian assistance. There are many other countries that are deserving too, but we do have that unique relationship with PNG that we cannot walk away from. Thursday, 4 December 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 12157 Sharpening the focus is a very good report. It is the result of an excellent seminar and I commend those who participated. I believe, as the ministerial statement says, it is a vehicle which does give us a better chance to sell to the wider Australian community the purposes and advantages of maintaining an adequate level of funding for Australian aid. It has worked well under AusAID; it worked well before under AIDAB. I believe it will continue to work well in the future. I would hope that the observations which have emerged from the aid report, particularly in terms of assessing the value of Australian aid, refocusing aid management, giving an Australian identity to our aid program, and assessing one program against anotherparticularly in terms of sectoral priorities-are factors which are important. We do need to recognise, however, that assessment of the value of aid is something which perhaps has not been done sufficiently in the past. I believe that it is worthwhile, as the minister has said, to set up a permanent advisory committee to advise the minister on aid and development issues. That committee will enable him to hear directly from the broader community about Australia's aid efforts. We need to make sure we get the best value out of it and, certainly, from those wonderful people and the non-government organisations. I would like to commend the NGOs. So many of them give an enormous amount. I think we are very fortunate in Australia that we have not only those who commit official government funds to aid but those in the Australian Volunteers Abroad scheme and so many other volunteers. These people do an enormous amount without thought of adequate return. That dimension of Australian aid enhances the quality and character of who we are as Australians. I commend them and certainly would like to thank them for their participation in our seminar. It was a very effective and successful seminar. I commend the minister for having picked up so many of the ideas that we discussed on that occasion. was one of a number held by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. It also had a specific objective at the direction from the Minister for Foreign Affairs( Mr Downer) who wanted discussion on the Simons report. There has been wide-ranging discussion. This seminar was only one of a number of seminars held on it. Other seminars have been held in other places. I think that that was good and I congratulate the minister for the initiative there. I also would like to endorse the comments that the honourable member for New England( Mr Sinclair) just made about those working in the aid field. Whether it is through the official aid agency Au sAID or the NGOs, they do a tremendous job. The Minister for Foreign Affairs rightly identified the existence of mass poverty as the single most important economic and social issue on our planet today. Eliminating the disparities between the world's rich and poor is one of the crucial international challenges of our time. There is no doubt that the overall success of development in recent decades has been very significant: many more people live longer, fewer mothers die in childbirth and fewer infants die from preventable diseases. But the numbers living in poverty have continued to grow. Too many people-indeed, 1.3 billion too many, as the minister has noted-live in extreme poverty and are denied their basic rights to health, decent shelter, clean water supply, sanitation and education. We as a' nation can make a contribution to the elimination of many of these things. Eliminating poverty is affordable and achievable. The major UN conferences of recent years have drawn together a broad framework for cooperation that should deliver sustained progress, but to succeed we clearly need to mobilise greater political will across the international
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hollis (Throsby) (10.14 A.m.)
theText: I am pleased to participate in this debate. The seminar12158 MAIN COMMITIEE Thursday, 4 December 1997 community. It is far too easy to put the questions of the elimination of poverty into the toohard basket. I am afraid that that is what many countries do: they recognise that there is a problem there, they see that they have other domestic problems, and they put this international problem in the far too-hard basket. The provision of development assistance by countries such as Australia does reflect a basic and fundamental obligation, an obligation deeply embedded in our core national values. It is our duty to care about other people, in particular those less well-off than ourselves. We have a moral duty to reach out to the poor and the needy. When the foreign minister announced the establishment of the review headed by Mr Paul Simons, he rightly said that Australia has an overseas aid program of which all Australians can be proud. In his press release on 28 May last year, he put the following on the record: Australia has an aid program it can be proud of. Millions of people around the world are now better off thanks to the help they've received from Australia. Our aid program administered by AusAID and delivered by Australian companies, individuals, non-government organisations and academic institutions is highly effective. There is a very large degree of continuity in approach, both in the Simons committee report and in the government's broad acceptance of its recommendations. The introduction to the report states: We do not advocate revolutionary change. That is typical of Australia, of course. The report continues: The basic arrangement of the aid program is sound. The design and management of the program should continue to be the responsibility of a single, independent agency. The countries of East Asia and the Pacific should continue to be the primary focus. Similarly, the response is not a statement signalling dramatic change. It is essentially a further step in the ongoing evolution of our overseas aid program, a program which enjoys strong bipartisan support. The opposition welcomed the establishment of the Simons review. In ever-changing international circumstances, the continued review of Australia's overseas aid program is critically important for maximising its effectiveness and for making sure that we maintain its primary focus of contributing to lasting poverty reduction, while advancing Australia's national interests. Australia's overseas aid program should, in cooperative partnership with developing countries and people, assist in building foundations for broadly based, equitably distributed and sustainable economic growth. We should encourage responsible national economic policies, including support for' the development of efficient, accountable and fair government administration. Our aid program should give priority to breaking down barriers to the participation by the poor in economic and social development, and especially support activities which enable women to contribute and to benefit from development. We should also seek to increase the productivity of the poor by facilitating access by them to productive assets and credit, and access to supporting activities including health care, education and training, and appropriate agricultural technology. In broad terms, these are the goals which find expression in the Simons report. In a number of respects, however, the report and the government's response to it fall short of what we Thursday, 4 December 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 12159 might have hoped for. ,One of these is the issue of human rights. Aid to reduce poverty must be based on fundamental human rights principles, including the right to development. The Simons report is unquestionably weak in the human rights area. It speaks loosely of support for good government. One is always interested in what the term 'good government' means. I recently had an interesting conversation with the honourable member for Lalor( Mr Barry Jones). He was questioning what is actually meant by 'good government'. It sometimes seems as though it is one of these weaselly phrases that people throw in which covers all things. We support good government but we are not quite sure exactly what people mean when they use the term. often explains to me things which I have some doubt about. I do not always necessarily go along with his explanation but I am always grateful when I receive it. tion on human rights, and the government's response is little better. For our part, Labor is determined to give a high priority to support for, and enhancement of, the full range of human rights for people in developing countries. To do so is a central and integrating element of our approach to overseas aid. Although there is no mention in the report, or in the minister's response to the report, of human rights, I must say in all fairness that I do strongly support recent directions outlined by the minister to strengthen human rights assistance in our aid programs. Like all members of parliament, I am often challenged on the aid question. One group in the community argues that Australia does not give enough overseas aid and claims that what it does give is poorly channelled. Another group points out the real or imagined economic problems we have in this country and suggests that, really, charity begins at home. Well, as I heard someone say the, other day, 'Charity does begin at home but it need not necessarily stay there though.' Some would say that there should be no government aid at all and that all aid should be raised through the private sector. I suppose that, as in all things, government action is a matter of competing interests, but I believe that this government has made a significant contribution to poverty alleviation through the Australian aid program. Of course, those who argue that Australia should give no overseas aid overlook the fact that much of this money is spent in Australia, or by employing Australians on overseas aid projects. I know the linking of aid to trade is a contentious issue. Nevertheless, it is an issue of considerable economic significance to many Australians. I have a point of disagreement with many of my friends in the aid field because I see nothing wrong with tied aid if we can not only give some assistance to the elimination of poverty--or whatever the aid is going for-but also give some assistance in Australia. I recently heard the Leader of the National Party( Mr Tim Fischer) talking about aid-it might have been at one of the seminars or in this chamber-and he made the very valid point, I thought, that one of the ways he could sell aid to his rural constituency was to tie it in with a trade thing. Some of the academic arguments on aid do not always agree with that. They say that it should be given to an international organisation or it should just be given. Well, I went to PNG a couple of years ago and I saw the result of untied aid there. And, ever since, I have been a firm advocate for the provision of tied aid.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Nugent
theText: Listen when I make my contribution and I'll explain.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hollis
theText: I am always grateful to the honourable member for Aston, because he so
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nehl)
theText: --':'He's a very helpful member.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hollis
theText: It is significant that the Simons report does not have a single recommenda12160 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 December 1997 Ultimately, however, overseas aid is about practical outcomes and the allocation of real resources. Commissioning reports and reviews is no substitute for real political commitment to deliver the goods and to be held accountable for one's performance. As I said earlier in my remarks, we clearly need to mobilise greater political will across the international community if the world is to successfully meet the challenge of global poverty. Mr Deputy Speaker, like other members of parliament, I visited many Australian overseas projects and I have always found them to be well run and of great benefit wherever they are. I guess that when the question of aid is raised with you by constituents, as it is with me, the Mekong Friendship Bridge is always mentioned. I actually doubt that any other issue has generated as much misinformation as the Mekong Friendship Bridge. I visited this bridge in 1994. As you know, it is the first road link between Laos and Thailand and will yield significant economic benefits to both countries. If anyone needs any proof of this, they have only to look at the entrepreneurial activities that are already taking place on the Thai side of the bridge. One of the other things that people often overlook about that bridge is that it is one of the highest profile aid projects undertaken by Australia in recent years. It was completed under time and under budget and the bridge is a showcase for what Australians can deliver in technology, design and infrastructure transfer. As such, it is very important in our expanding trade relationship with Asia. Mr Deputy Speaker, population issues have continued to be an important aspect of Australia's overseas aid program. As one who is convinced that overpopulation and economic underdevelopment are closely linked, I welcome the emphasis in our aid program on population issues. The priority which the aid program affords population issues was reflected in the major role that All,,tralia played at the International Conference on Population and Development held in Calro in December 1994. Australia was active in encouraging the international conference to adopt the groundbreaking program of action for the empowerment of women and called for major increases in global resources for family planning and health services. Australia has, unfortunately, cut, in the first budget of the Howard government, our assistance to some of the UN programs and the International Planned Parenthood Federation and although in the last budget they were not cut again that funding was not restored. I know that there are serious budgetary considerations that everyone has got to look at but I do hope that in the foreseeable future that funding can be restored to the UN Fund for Population and Development and especially the International Planned Parenthood Federation. In the budgetary context it is not a huge amount of money but to those organisations it is and it has a significant impact on programs that the IPPF were undertaking in our region in the Pacific Islands. Quite frankly, we have a special responsibility to this area. The Americans have withdrawn recently from aid programs in the Pacific Islands. I do not think the New Zealanders are in a position to contribute much more than they do. Unless we pick up the challenge no-one else will. I hope that the government will look at that very carefully and maybe restore some of the funding that was cut a couple of years ago. I sometimes think that Australia wants to do less with less money but Australia can do more and if we do not do more we are failing in our responsibility. We are also passing up an opportunity, especially in our part of the world, to playa significant leadership role and I think that that is a responsibility that we should take up. Thursday, 4 December 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 12161 I congratulate all those associated with the seminar. It was a worthwhile seminar and is part of the excellent series of programs that the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee has been carrying out over these last couple of years. week immediately after the gentleman from Throsby( Mr Hollis). said but he did not stay. This time. I am not going to pick him up on very much. He concluded on a point that I think often strikes at the very heart of the whole aid debate. That is that we would like to spend more but obviously times are tight and it is not always possible. Some very hard decisions have to be made on where you are going to spend the money because there are so many competing causes on which one would like to spend money. I think one of the most difficult things is-and Mr Hollis drew attention to the fact-that some particular funding that he was interested in would have been a relatively small contribution for the government to make. I was in India and Pakistan last year and I remember in Pakistan going to a particular village on the outskirts of Islamabad where poverty was quite appalling. I think the honourable gentleman from Maribyrnong ( Mr Sercombe) was with me. It was incredible irony that we had had a meeting with the president of Pakistan which was scheduled for half an hour but ran for about an hour and a half. That was the president, I might add, who I think today was removed from office in Pakistan. most incredible poverty. They had actually survived for some years with a donation of about $100,000 from Australia. We had just announced to these kids and families who were living in the most appalling conditions that we were withdrawing our support. One was tempted to say: how could we possibly do that? Of course, the irony was further stretched in that, because we got there late, we did not stay there for very long, and we were then pressured to go to the Prime Minister's residence for lunch. We went to the Prime Minister's residence for lunch, cutting our visit to this village short because of the time pressures. We then sat around waiting for ages and found we were not having lunch with the Prime Minister, but with the Prime Minister's husband, who was then minister for development or something like that. arrive. We then proceeded to dine off gold plates in the most incredible opulence, a matter of a handful of kilometres from where we had seen this poverty. One, of course, was saying, 'Well, why isn't some of that money being spent in their own country on the poor people?' I am not making a particular judgment in this case. I am merely trying to identify that there are incredibly difficult choices to be made in this whole area. I did promise the member for Throsby by way of interjection during his contribution that I would try to enlighten him on the subject of governance. He referred to a conversation he had had with the honourable member for Lalor( Mr Barry Jones) about the subject of governance and what it meant. The honourable member for Lalor, of course, often makes very

speaker: Mr Nugent
theText: He is now in gaol. We sat there waiting for nearly an hour for him to12162 MAIN COMMIITEE Thursday, 4 December 1997 worthy intellectual contributions in this place. He has discussed this subject with me, and I think, frankly, that he gets hung up a bit on the use of language. It seems to me that governance in this area has a fairly straightforward definition. Governance really comprises any measures that we can take to assist a country that is in difficulties-Third World countries, obviously-to run the show better. That might take a number of forms. It may involve lending them some experts in the form of public servants to help plan the economy and the budget. It may be lending them parliamentary draftsmen to assist with the drafting of theit legislation-although sometimes, seeing some of our drafting, I am not so sure about that. We have, on occasions, seconded or sent for visits for training clerks from our own parliament to the parliaments of other countries to assist them in their procedures and the way they run the place. It seems to me that governance is all about trying to develop, train and bring on a lot of those Third World countries so that the countries are run more effectively and efficiently. It seems to me that that is a very important thing for us to do in the long term. Prior to the contribution by the member for Throsby, we heard from the right honourable member for New England( Mr Sinclair). I would support three of his comments. I commend members of the Simons committee. I also commend Australian NGOs who do such an incredible job overseas, usually in quite difficult circumstances. I am particularly impressed with, for example, the volunteers from organisations such as AESOP. I also agree with the key thrust of the contribution by the right honourable member for New England when he talked about the importance of making people better off in order to secure stability in their country and in the region and because that is the best way to advance human rights. I think those are important key points. Mr Deputy Speaker, we are here this morning to talk about the Simons committee report and the seminar that was held by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign affairs, Defence and Trade into that report. As we have already heard, to some extent that seminar has now been overtaken by the reality of the government's response which was made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs( Mr Downer) on 18 November this year in a ministerial statement entitled 'Better aid for a better future'. I would like to remind the House that the government now has established six principles in terms of the way that it will administer aid in the future. These include: adopting a partnership approach; responding to urgent needs in emergency situations; providing practical assistance; applying greater targeting-not a scatter gun approach, but really being more focused in the way we do things; ensuring that programs remain identifiably Australian; and ensuring that programs are outward looking-in other words, not just doing what we have done before but looking around the world for best practice and new, innovative and more effective ways of delivering our aid. The government has also identified five key sectors in which aid will be distributed: health, education, infrastructure, rural development, and governance-that word that the gentleman from Throsby had some difficulty with, and which I have already addressed. In the time left to me, I would like to paint a few word pictures from my own experience, because we all travel and look at aid projects when we go overseas whenever we can. I would like to give a few examples of some of the things that Australian aid is doing, because I think it is important that the public understand the sorts of uses that our aid is put to. Thursday, 4 December 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 12163 Let me give an example in that first key area of health. I was recently in the South Pacific and one of the countries I went to was Vanuatu. As a result of television as, everybody in Australia thinks of Vanuatu as a holiday destination. We got in at Port Vila at about 1 0' clock in the morning and at six o'clock the next morning-we did not have long in bed-we were on a rickety old plane going out to one of the southern islands called Tanna. Tanna is hardly a nice holiday destination. At that stage, we visited the hospital. The hospital was about to close down its generator for lack of fuel due to shipping strikes. The conditions in the hospital were really quite appalling. In this country our animals are sent to better buildings and conditions when they go to the vet than the people who were being looked after in this place. Tanna is staffed by a single doctor, who was a volunteer from Canada. The doctors in the city of Victoria on Vanc01.-ver Island in Canada have got together and sent one of their number for six months at a time to be the doctor on Tanna. The doctors do it voluntarily and it is unpaid. All the costs and so on are funded by the doctor community in Victoria. A number of Australian organisations have been there to help put in generators, other equipment and so on. Quite clearly, the basic health problems in Tanna are quite serious. Unless the standard of health is improved, then the kids are not going to be able to go to school and get their education. If they cannot get their education, then they are not going to get jobs. It is a very similar scenario in many ways to a lot of the indigenous communities in this country. But in Tanna we were providing assistance to that hospital and it was very vitally needed assistance. It is a basic building block to get the people in that location back on their feet. An example in the education area is Kiribati, which I visited on the same trip to the South Pacific. Kiribati is a country of about 77,000 people. Its area of land on many little islands is quite small, but it is spread over more than 3,500 kilometres of ocean. In other words, there is a huge area of sea and very little land. It is bigger than Australia from east to west, but the area of land is less than the size of Canberra. Clearly, education is a problem because they cannot afford to have schools on every island in every community. So particularly at the secondary level, they bring the children from all over the country to a single location on a particular island where they run their secondary school-and sometimes it takes three weeks to路 get to school. Obviously, the children board there. So apart from needing the basics of education, they need to have living facilities as well. The straw huts on mud earth that the kids used to have to live in for 11 months of the year-they only go to their home island for a month during the long school holiday-were really quite appalling. Australia has built an accommodation block, which has improved the conditions incredibly. And you would think that was great. But I walked into that accommodation block with other members of the delegation. Of course, it has a concrete floor and the kids are sleeping on the concrete floor. They have no private lockers to keep their things in, they each have a suitcase or a bag of some sort. So it is very primitive accommodation, although it is a heck of a lot better than it was before. Clearly, what we have done there will help those children in terms of their standard of living. It will help them to be in better shape to learn and to be educated and therefore better fitted to take on a role later in life. Infrastructure is obviously a key area. I was in Laos recently and we visited a village in the south of the country. We travelled in a rather rickety 30-year-old Russian helicopter. In this village of 400 or 500 people, they have had to tramp several miles-usually the women12164 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 December 1997 carrying a bucket on their head to try to draw water from a very muddy, polluted river and then bring it all the way back to the village. That, of course, had the inevitable impact of disease and so on. What Australian aid managed to do, for $100, was to sink a bore and a well in the middle of the village and provide them for the first time ever with fresh, clean, drinking water. So not only did it stop all that labour of having to walk for miles, but it provided better quality water on hand which clearly is going to improve the health standards of that particular village-and for $100. It is absolutely incredible. The other thing that Australia did was to build a dam on the local river-which flows mightily during the wet season and stops during the dry season-for a few thousand dollars, which will supply them with water to grow their crops throughout the year. Those sorts of basic infrastructure projects are most important. The previous speaker mentioned the Mekong bridge which links Laos with Thailand. Australia is also building a number of other bridges in the southern part of Laos because you cannot get by road from the north to the south of the country, so how do you get communications going; how do you develop the country economically; how does it get back on its feet if you have not got a road? Because of the number of rivers, one of the key things is that you need to provide bridges as well. I could go on at some length, Madam Deputy Speaker, but I see that my time is about to expire. In the few seconds remaining to me, I would like to say that nearest to home we have PNG, which is of major concern to us and I think it could be the subject of a whole new debate. I would like to commend the report to the chamber. morning to contribute to this debate on the government's response to the Simons report on Australia's aid program. In his introduction to this response, the Minister for Foreign Affairs( Mr Downer) said: Mass poverty is the single most important economic and social issue on our planet today. I have spoken in the House before about the desperate need of those who are trapped in mass poverty, particularly in the developing nations. Nineteen ninety-six was the International Year for the Eradication of Poverty but, unfortunately, poverty was not eradicated. It is true that more focus was drawn to the needs of the poverty stricken in that year and we as a government will continue to work in partnership with the people in those countries to alleviate some of their suffering. There are many ordinary Australian families who playa financially supportive role in the alleviation of poverty through World Vision and other child sponsorship programs. Australians as a people are generous with their gifts to those in need. But one of the best ways we can help alleviate poverty in the world is to help those in poverty to help themselves. It was pleasing to note the government's agreed objective that our Australian overseas aid program will be-and I quote: ... 'to advance Australia's national interests by assisting developing countries to reduce poverty and achieve sustainable development'. The aid program will be focused and targeted to maximise the outcomes for investment made. I have had a long association with the Results group in my electorate who have actively lobbied Commonwealth governments, both Labor and coalition, to create the political will to
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Charles (La Trobe) (10.43 A.m.)
theText: I am delighted to have the opportunity thisThursday, 4 December 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 12165 end hunger and poverty throughout the world. I would like to read a note I received from two of their members earlier this week: At last we see the Government response to the Simons report. It's great to hear that the Government has endorsed poverty reduction as the main goal of foreign aid and retained the target of .7% of GNP and that aid projects will now get greater supervision and scrutiny. Wow. What happens now? This government will provide an effective and well-targeted aid program, focussing on the alleviation of poverty and the promotion of sustainable development. Our focus will also be on meeting the priority needs of the partner countries. Aid is a partnership between the giver and the receiver. We, in this government, are very much aware of the partnership aspects of our aid programs. The best partnerships are those where all partners enjoy a mutual benefit, and that is the aim of our aid program. One of the most successful methods of obtaining that mutual benefit is through micro-credit. The Grameen Bank has a proud record of providing small loans to people in developing countries. Many of the borrowers are women who may use the money to buy a few chickens that they can breed for eating or to produce eggs that they will sell. The money might be used to buy a sewing machine to set up a small sewing business. Other loans have been used to buy two or three cows for milking. Many of these enterprises have achieved incredible success for the borrowers, have lifted them out of the depths of poverty, and even allowed families to send their children to school. Micro-credit gives people the opportunity to escape the poverty trap through their own efforts and own achievement with dignity-a hand-up, not a handout. Basic education is another focus of our aid program. The annual report states: Education is development's most basic building block and is vital for alleviating poverty. Our education efforts will concentrate on building a broad range of education assistance, with a particular focus on basic and technical education. We all know from our own experience in Australia that, without the most basic literacy and numeracy skills, people's futures are limited. This is even more so in the developing world, particularly for women and girls. For sustainable development to occur, countries need essential infrastructure and, in particular, a clean and safe water supply-a basic necessity which we often take for granted. If more of us were to travel in Third World countries, where the water supply is almost non-existent and what is available is undrinkable, we might better appreciate the value of the water that we have in this country. In India, for example, it often is not even safe to swim in rivers because of the pollution, contamination and waterborne diseases. Our aid resources will carefully target vital infrastructure services to ensure that private funding is not displaced, while reaching those people most in need. Micro-hydro is one way of helping remote and small communities without damage to the environment and at minimal cost. The annual report states: Preventing environmental degradation is essential to alleviation of poverty and ensuring development is sustainable. Very poor people concentrate on day to day survival ... poor health prohibits them from earning income and overcoming poverty. Australia's aid program will make that investment in sustainable agriculture, improved sanitation, clean water and better management of national resources. We know that these issues 12166 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 December 1997 are critical to the alleviation of poverty. Australia is committed to working in partnership with the receiving countries to address these environmental issues. All of the above broad based programs for economic growth, sustainable development and individual empowerment will contribute to the reduction of poverty that the Simons report has recommended. Despite the Simons report recommendation that the aid volume target of 0.7 per cent be reduced, the government will continue to recognise the UN target of 0.7 per cent of GNP as an indicative target. All foreign aid, like all other government programs, will be considered in the annual budget context. I am pleased to note the government has accepted the recommendations to focus our Australian aid program on the Asia-Pacific region. This is our geographical home and the focus of our region are our neighbours. Although in economic and technological terms the world is shrinking, Australia is not about to float away to somewhere else. It is right that our aid programs should be focused on Papua New Guinea and the Pacific and East Asia, and selectively in South Asia, Africa and the Middle East. Priorities will be on a development needs basis in conjunction with Australia's broader interests. The minister has noted that the Simons report made 79 recommendations, of which the government has accepted 64 fully, in part or in principle; nine have been rejected, of which reducing the UN target of 0.7 per cent was one; and six have been noted for further consideration. The government's response to the Simons report is responsible and fair. The recommendations rejected have been judged against the overall aid program. This government and, indeed, Australia as a nation have a proud record of aid to the developing world. We will continue to focus that aid on the alleviation of poverty through individual empowerment, sustainable development, primary health and basic education that is of benefit to all parties involved. I recommend the government's response to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Sercombe) adjourned. Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Report Debate resumed from 20 October 1997, on motion by Mr Sinclair: That the House take note of the paper. wealth is something that most of us do not really think about daily as we go about our lives. It is an organisation which, for some, is still associated more with the days of empire than it is with today. It was for that reason and because of the imminence of CHOGM-the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting-in Edinburgh that we decided it would be worthwhile conducting, on 20 August last, the seminar on the Commonwealth of Nations. This report, From Empire to partnership, lists those who participated. It sets out the actual text of the quite significant contributions made. It also comes forward with a report from our committee making some comment on the dialogue at the seminar and making some recommendations, and it is on those that I want to say a few things this morning. On the Commonwealth itself, I think its relevance to our daily lives is perhaps more through sport, and perhaps in some of the other visits that we receive, than in any other form. It is, of course, the countries predominantly of the British Commonwealth. We now have, however, one country in the African region that was a colony of another power, and there is an increasing feeling amongst a lot of countries that the nature of the Commonwealth changing
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sinclair (New England) (10.51 A.m.)
theText: The nature and character of the CommonThursday, 4 December 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 12167 brings with it the prospect of our forgetting some aspects of that original association and bringing us into a new grouping which does give perhaps new life for the future. The first thing I should say is that the role of the Commonwealth emerged, for most of us, as being far more significant and having far more meaning for Australia than many of us had expected. Certainly, from my point of view, I came away from the Commonwealth seminar feeling that, in spite of my own reservations over the years, there was an ongoing role for Australia as a member of the Commonwealth and that the Commonwealth was a worthwhile international organisation. I say that as one who was a little amazed at the extent to which successive prime ministers have taken unto themselves the role of being statesman in CHOGM and seen that as a way to enhance their international egos. That probably is a bit harsh on some, but unfortunately it is true of them all. It has been quite remarkable that all of them-and I say 'all of them', from my experience from Menzies to Howard-have found that the dialogue at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting has given them a stature that I think they do not feel they receive at home. That is a good thing. Apart from anything else it gives them an opportunity to talk with a lot of other heads of state. Sometimes we are a bit critical of outcomes. If the Commonwealth is to achieve anything then it will be more to do with preserving what we all respect in our British heritage. When you look at Nigeria, you cannot say that it has done so. There are three matters I would like to mention here. Firstly, I would like to see the principle of the rule of law accepted so that there is an independent judiciary, there are rights for people to act on behalf of accused persons, and there is a set structure of law which is not based on providing benefits to the few but rather allowing equal rights to all within society. Secondly, our British heritage brings with it the tradition of a free press. While most of us, certainly all politicians, are fairly critical of the press and the press does need to be more responsible, that does not in any way deny the need for us to preserve the concept of an independent, free media. These days when the electronic media has provided such an enormous opportunity for people, whatever their background, to see what is going on immediately it happens, that freedom of the media becomes even more important. So, the rule of law and a free media are two very important matters. The third issue, which almost flows from those two but, tragically, does not apply in many countries, concerns democratic institutions. I am referring to the opportunity for people to determine who is going to be their government in a fair, free and open electoral system. Unfortunately, some of the members of the Commonwealth do not follow that principle either. To my mind, those three issues are the most important benefits of Commonwealth membership. I regret that some Commonwealth countries have set aside those basic principles. Yet, without those principles, coming to fair and equitable resolution of difficult domestic problems is extraordinarily difficult. At the moment Nigeria is suspended from membership. Fiji was suspended but has now returned. I hope that there can be ongoing efforts to try to lift the profile of those issues because they are the most important part of being members of the Commonwealth. Let me return briefly to the conclusions and recommendations in the report. We looked at what we saw as the benefits to the Commonwealth, and there are several benefits from Australia's perspective. The sporting association is undoubted. We all look forward to the Commonwealth Games in Kuala Lumpur next year. They will provide yet again a wonderful 12168 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 December 1997 opportunity for Australian athletes to compete internationally and to gain experience in another environment. That is very good and we should endorse those Commonwealth contacts. Of course, there are problems in any international sporting competition to do with what sports should be included and with ensuring that drugs are not seen as permissible and hence distorting what are normal competitive opportunities. In terms of determining what sports should be included, I have always thought that international games like the Commonwealth Games are better if confined to individual sports and that team sports are better played in other environments. Be that as it may, it is very good that there are these Commonwealth Games. Amongst the recommendations we looked at other fields, including the educational field. Our first recommendation suggests: ... the establishment of a Commonwealth resources centre. We had in mind looking at how we can provide opportunities for improving education levels and contact between Commonwealth countries. Another recommendations which I very strongly support, and I hope the government might support, is: That, the Australian Government, as part of its aid program, set aside a defined number of scholarships for students from Commonwealth countries to assist with tertiary and post-graduate education in Australia. I wanted to mention that because in our aid program in Africa, for example, we have tended to forget there are a lot of smaller countries that receive very little aid. Yet those few scholarships we have provided in the past were a very good vehicle to help numbers of residents of those countries to lift their standard of living, their understanding and their education and so go back home and lift the general quality of government and quality of life in their own countries. In education I think there is a role that the Commonwealth can play. Australia should take a lead in promoting those educational scholarships, but of course not only Australia. I would. like to see all the countries of the Commonwealth offer similar educational opportunities for people of other countries. I know that in the past many have gone to Britain. Today the same opportunities exist, certainly in all of the countries of what is called the old Commonwealth. But in the new Commonwealth countries too some of the education institutions are very good and reciprocity in that field is worthwhile. The first area was sport and the second was education. The third that I want to tum to is the suggestion that perhaps we might reinstitute a regional Commonwealth heads of government meeting. We seem to have a great plethora of international groups. We have got APEC and the ARF, the ASEAN Regional Forum. We even have the finance ministers plus six group. We have various defence arrangements and people might well say, 'Well, you've got a Commonwealth heads of government meeting. What on earth do you want a regional heads of government meeting for?' One of the reasons I think it is important at the moment is that Britain has withdrawn from east of Suez totally now-it has got its residual interest in Pitcairn about which I spoke yesterday. Apart from that, what we want to do is to try to look at our region. The countries of our region include some very fragile ecosystems in the Pacific islands. Many of them are members of the British Commonwealth and if we had a regional heads of government meeting-I know we have got a South Pacific Forum and a South Pacific Commission but this would be a bit different-it would provide in areas I think are important that I have mentioned before-democratic institutions, the rule of law and a free press-an opportunity for people to talk about the systems of government. For example, PNG is a member of the Thursday, 4 December 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 12169 Commonwealth. How beneficial it would be if the people of PNG were constantly being reminded of the principles that, in a democracy such as theirs, seem to be stretched by patronage and corruption which, if the present media reports are to be believed, again threaten its. very viability. I think a regional Commonwealth heads of government meeting would be worthwhile from time to time so we could have a look at some of the ways in which we could help each other. It would provide an opportunity to get Britain perhaps and the old Commonwealth-I would include countries like India and Pakistan-to look at problems in our region and see whether or not we might be able to help each other to a greater degree. That was another recommendation we included in our report. We have mentioned also the promotion of democratic values. I think that is worthwhile. Recommendation 6, in fact, picks up those general points that I have been making. We talk about the Commonwealth Games Association. We talk also about non-government organisations. Because we all start from the same principles, there is a great advantage in looking at Commonwealth NGOs. CARE, for example, is one of those which does a great job. I think that it is important that we find ways to promote NGOs to assist the government funded aid by working through Red Cross, CARE and other bodies which have an international association. Quite often, our Australian-based NGOs can get additional finance and additional resources and can better address the problems that are still so regrettably abundant around the world. We believe that it is worthwhile to support the work of Commonwealth NGOs and we can do this in a number of ways. Again, this was an aspect that was discussed fairly extensively at the seminar. We also thought it might be worthwhile having a regional Commonwealth trade ministers meeting. The Commonwealth is, of course, not a trade association, but I confess that it has never really pleased me greatly having members of our royal family going about promoting British trade interests. I felt that it would be far better if they recognised that they are really there, if they are promoting trade, to promote the trade of the Commonwealth rather than of any individual member of it. We felt, having looked at some of the aspects of trade, that Commonwealth trade and finance ministers might be able to meet from time to time with some benefit to all of the participants. The final area mentioned was human rights. We did look at problems. I have mentioned Nigeria. Many members of the Commonwealth are, regrettably, virtually one-party states. These countries have human rights practices which are at a level which is less than what Australians would regard as acceptable. It is important that we find ways in which we can strengthen consideration of human rights issues. We felt that it was worthwhile strengthening the role and resources of the Commonwealth's human rights unit so that we might be able to promote and protect human rights in the member countries. I thought the seminar was well worthwhile. We had an excellent day's discussion. As one who has long been cynical about aspects of the Commonwealth, I felt that it displayed that Australia not only has an ongoing role within the Commonwealth, but has a contribution to make. In that respect, I would hope that, with the constitutional convention coming up, one of the issues on which there will not be a great deal of debate is that Australia should continue-whatever the outcome of our own sovereignty question-to be a member of the Commonwealth and that the Queen should remain at its head. 12170 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 December 1997 I commend this report to members and to the wider community. It emphasises the extent to which we have transferred from the old empire to a modern partnership. It is no longer the British Commonwealth; it is very much a Commonwealth of partners and of equals, and I think Australia has a very important role to play in it. I recommend that the government should accept each of the recommendations included within our paper attached to the seminar proceedings. on 20 August 1997 was one of a number that the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade has conducted over the last year. As I said in speaking to reports of the other seminars, they have been excellent seminars which have been very well attended-not necessarily so well attended by members of parliament, which I think is a pity, but very well attended by some members of parliament, the academic community, the defence and diplomatic communities. I doubt whether we see the relevance of the Commonwealth today. For too many people, there were elements of a colonial relationship there, and they did not regard it as a meeting of equals. A point referred to by the right honourable member for New England( Mr Sinclair) is that one of the reasons---or a symbol, if you like, rather than a reason-is that Her Majesty the Queen, although head of the Commonwealth, is very much seen as the Queen of England. Something that has always niggled me a little bit is when Her Majesty the Queen visits somewhere as Queen of England and promotes British industry and trade. If we are to take that role seriously, Her Majesty the Queen, as head of the Commonwealth, in a way should not play a role in promoting one country over another, or she should promote all countries. The Commonwealth does play an important role. Currently, there are 53 members. Again, one of the points made by the right honourable member for New England-I do not want to have to agree with everything he said-was something I had thought about myself. I debated whether I wanted to attend this seminar because I was always quite sceptical about the Commonwealth. I was quite sceptical about its worth. I thought it was part of the past of Australia and I, like many people, saw our future in Asia and places like that. I thought: what relevance has the Commonwealth got for us today? Very rarely is a member of parliament persuaded by a one-day seminar held in Parliament House, but I came away from that seminar with a completely changed view on the role of the Commonwealth. NowI am a very strong advocate for the role that the Commonwealth can play in so many fields-not only the sporting links that we all talk about, but the trade links and the political links. After that one-day seminar, I was very much convinced of the worth ofMr Sinclair interjectingmore members of parliament did not attend, for the range of speakers and the quality of the debate was excellent. I would strongly recommend to people that they should read the report on the proceedings because there were some excellent contributions that day. Membership of the Commonwealth is entirely voluntary and a number of former British dependencies, mandates or protectorates, such as Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Burma and the Sudan,
title: Representatives Main Commitiee

speaker: Mr Hollis (Throsby) (11.06 A.m.)
theText: The seminar on the Commonwealth of Nations held
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sawford
theText: The member is mellowing!
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hollis
theText: The member is mellowing or looking at all sides.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hollis
theText: That was because of the excellence of that seminar. It is a great pity thatThursday, 4 December 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 12171 and several of the Gulf states, decided against membership when achieving independence. It might have been a very different Commonwealth if they had come in. Some countries have also left and, in some cases, later have rejoined the Commonwealth. Ireland withdrew its membership in 1949, and South Africa did not reapply for admission after becoming a republic in 1961, finally being readmitted on 1 June 1994. Pakistan left in 1972 and rejoined on 1 October 1989. Fiji's membership lapsed when it did not reapply after adopting a republican constitution following the military coup in 1987. At the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in November 1995, Nigeria's membership was suspended due to concerns about persistent human rights violations. There are many countries which have applied to join the Commonwealth. For example, the most recent member of the Commonwealth is Mozambique, a country with no historic links with the British Empire. It was admitted to the Commonwealth in 1995 as 'a unique and special case'. It is the first Commonwealth member to be neither formerly under British rule, nor that of another Commonwealth country. Nor does it use the English language substantially for top-level political and administrative purposes. During the seminar it was felt that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was not devoting sufficient attention and emphasis to the Commonwealth. This is particularly important with regard to trade. The importance of the economic dimension of the Commonwealth was recognised in the setting of the theme-trade, investment and development matters--of the 1997 CHOGM. The significance of the Commonwealth in economic issues was clearly acknowledged in 1996 by the House of Commons Foreign Affairs Committee report. While it is still the case that some members of the Commonwealth are amongst the poorest in the world and rightly deserve the help and support of the richer developed world, the organisation now also contains some of the world's fastest growing economies--or it did when I wrote this speech; some things change quite dramatically these days-and even some of the richest. The Commonwealth today embraces what may well tum out to be one of the world's fastest growing markets. Could it be that the very features which were seen by some as Commonwealth weaknesses in previous areas, such as a transregional character and its diversity, could now prove to be its strength? At the August seminar, the academic and author, Katherine West, spoke of the importance of the Commonwealth as economies become more globalised and competitive, providing as it does opportunities for regional and transregional networking. Even some of the most sceptical members are now expressing far more positive perceptions of the Commonwealth as a low-cost, ready-made transregional network, or a series of networks-according to Ms West-through which members in one region can improve their capacity to benefit from economic and diplomatic opportunities as well as other regions of the world. While the Commonwealth contains some of the richest countries, as I have said, and countries with extremely high economic growth rates, it also includes some of the poorest countries in the world; There are great variations in per capita income, economic strength, and ability to participate in international trade and investment across the Commonwealth countries. Of the 53 Commonwealth members, some 29 are defined as small-that is, having populations of less than one million-and 14 have fewer than 200,000 people. Small states are a continuing focus of the Commonwealth work and now receive about 65 per cent of the Commonwealth's technical assistance. The Commonwealth does not have a legal regime in place to address human rights issues, but such concerns were central to the 12172 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 December 1997 Singapore declaration in 1971, the Harare declaration in 1991 and, most recently, in the Millbrook action plan arising from the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Auckland in 1995. The Singapore declaration sought to strengthen the influence of the United Nations for international peace and security, to strive to promote institutions and guarantees for personal freedom under law, to combat racial prejudice in colonialism, to overcome poverty, ignorance and disease and to achieve a more equitable international society. These principles were affirmed in the Harare declaration, described by the then Commonwealth Secretary-General as 'a landmark to guide our association'. In that declaration, the heads of government reaffirmed their commitment to equal rights and opportunities for all citizens regardless of race, colour, creed or political belief; to equality for women; and to the provision of universal access to education for all their populations. They pledged the Commonwealth to work with renewed vigour in the protection and promotion of the fundamental political values of the Commonwealth-democracy, the rule of law, just and honest government and fundamental human rights. They decided on continuing action to help end apartheid and bring democracy to South Africa, in which they were successful. The human rights record of many Commonwealth countries is poor. Although it is unwise to generalise, there are difficulties in many states ranging from comparative minor abuses-,...if such a thing really does exist in regard to human rights-to appalling violations of the most basic of human rights. As the seminar was told, the contemporary commonplace disregard of human rights means that a post-apartheid, post-colonial Commonwealth offers cold comfort to common people. Ms Gilmore, the National Director of Amnesty International, documented a number of specific human rights abuses across a range of Commonwealth countries. She also noted the wide variations amongst Commonwealth countries in regard to the international agreements on human rights. I think this is one area where the Commonwealth can play a much more positive role in regard to human rights. We make much in this country-and, indeed, in much of the Commonwealth-about the Westminster parliamentary system of democracy. We make much of the basis of our law, which is the common law which has evolved through the ages in the United Kingdom. It is also the case-and I know this is a point that the right honourable member for New England touched on-with the education system. So often we talk about the education system. The education system, and especially the higher education system, in this country has evolved very much from the British education system. Despite what people might or might not believe about what happens in Northern Ireland, I think that the British have a good record on human rights. It seems to me that, as a member of the Commonwealth, we can set a higher penalty for violations of human rights because there are tremendous violations of human rights in many of the Commonwealth countries. I think that diminishes the work of the Commonwealth. The role of the Commonwealth is changing and evolving. It is a modem partnership today. It has its weaknesses, especially with regard to human rights. I think that some times some members of the Commonwealth are a little reticent to comment on the internal affairs of another country. As far as I am concerned, human rights overcomes that. I am not one who necessarily subscribes to the United Nations charter article 2 paragraph 7. Some internal affairs of countries should override that part of the United Nations convention. Thursday, 4 December 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 12173 As I said earlier, it was an excellent seminar. I congratulate all involved in it. I would recommend to my parliamentary colleagues-I know the amount of reading they have to dothat they have a look through this report because they will be, as I was, quite surprised with the quality of the debate at that conference that day. I commend this report to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Tuckey) adjourned. Electoral Matters Committee Report Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Mr Nairn: That the House take note of the paper. into the role of the Australian Electoral Commission in conducting industrial elections. I should say that it is not commonly appreciated that not only trade unions but also employer organisations are industrial organisations. The report is as equally relevant to those employer organisations as it is to trade unions. The report is a very balanced and constructive document. It is really quite astounding that it is a unanimous report in circumstances where there could be thought to have been some controversy. Indeed, there were some questions and answers in the federal parliament indicating that the inquiry may have been in the nature of a witch hunt or a scapegoating exercise. That certainly was not the case. I think it is to the credit of the chairman and members of the committee generally that they were able to come up with very sensible terms of reference and produce such a constructive document. I also indicate appreciation for the role of Mr David Dick, who was seconded to assist the committee. He really was very talented in his knowledge of the area. As a matter of interest, he prepared one of the best historical analyses I have seen of legislation dealing with elections in industrial organisations. That in itself is very worthwhile reading for anyone who has an interest in the area. Overall, the report found that the Australian Electoral Commission conducts industrial elections in a very professional and even-handed manner. That was the evidence from not only trade unions but also employer organisations . .I think it could be regarded as quite an endorsement of the work of the Australian Electoral Commission. There were over 3,500 elections in industrial organisations between 1991 and 1996. Of that number, only 1.5 per cent has resulted in inquiries, and only a fraction of that 1.5 per cent has involved allegations of fraudulent conduct. The sensationalism that we can sometimes read in the media regarding trade union or industrial organisation elections occurs in a very small percentage of organisations. It has been noted that you can have all the penalties and regimes in the world in legislation, but that does not prevent fraudulent conduct. Fraud occurs anyway. By its nature, it is unlawful conduct. It is very difficult for a legislature to legislate to stamp out fraud. What the legislature can do, of course, is to prescribe penalties for fraudulent conduct and an enforcement regime. In the context of the report, we have recommended some strengthening of penalties and some procedures which we believe will minimise fraud, particularly as it could occur in the electoral process, by cross-verifying the information on the outside of an envelope, for instance, with the voter roll.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Mcclelland (Barton) (11.19 A.m.)
theText: I rise to take note of the report of the inquiry12174 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 4 December 1997 I think it is fair to say that some elements of the media would have liked to have seen a much more controversial, a much more sensational document. They have been sadly let down because it is not that. As I have said, it is an overall endorsement of the role of the Australian Electoral Commission in conducting industrial elections. Several witnesses place great emphasis on the findings of the Cooke inquiry in Queensland, which was conducted by Marshal Cooke, at the behest of the Queensland government, to inquire into the activities of five Queensland trade unions. People who compare our report to the report of the Cooke inquiry should bear in mind that the Cooke inquiry was established under Queensland legislation to look at five Queensland-registered trade unions, not federallyregistered organisations. Those five unions were referred to the Cooke inquiry because of some pre-existing controversy regarding their behaviour. So the more dramatic findings of the Cooke inquiry very much have to be seen in that context. We have the opportunity of reviewing the totality of the operations under the federal act, which is an entirely separate piece of legislation, the Industrial Relations Act 1988 and now the Workplace Relations Act. We were quite satisfied with the generality of how these elections are being conducted. Without exception, every organisation that attended to give evidence-and the peak body, the Australian Council of Trade Unions-was at pains to indicate their preparedness to assist in ensuring and developing a regime that gave the greatest credibility possible to the electoral processes within their organisations. They saw that it was important that the public had faith in their electoral processes. All gave balanced and sensible evidence in terms of taking the issue forward. In making recommendations which we believe will go some way to strengthening the procedures, we constantly have borne in mind the fundamental principles of freedom of association and the right of industrial organisations to regulate their own affairs. However, in our pluralist system of government, and our system generally, industrial organisations, be they employee organisations or employer organisations, have quite significant power and influence in the political process, the industrial process and these days the social and political 'debate. In that context, the public has a very substantial interest in ensuring that their affairs are regulated legitimately and transparently. So not only an organisation's individual members but also the public can have faith in the authority of their leadership. I mentioned earlier that one of the recommendations to come out of the report was standardisation of envelopes to avoid the situation we saw recently where a judge in one Federal Court case had some anxiety that voting papers may have gone astray or may have been filled in on a multiple basis by certain candidates on both sides in the election. We think that regime will substantially remove the possibility of irregularities occurring. We have also recommended that voting be conducted on the basis of membership cut-off roles. That is, there should be a cut-off between 30 and 60 days before the opening of the ballot to ensure that the membership rolls are in order and that all members who are legitimately entitled to participate in the ballot can and those who are not entitled to participate are excluded from the election. Also, we have recommended the establishment of a menu of model rules for industrial organisations-not in the sense of making those rules mandatory but in the sense of the standard articles of association which are a schedule in the Corporations Law. We believe that having such a menu of model rules will assist both industrial officials and lawyers, for instance, in advising organisations as to establishing a system for elections which as close as Thursday, 4 December 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 12175 possible accords with the law and accords with principles and practices to minimise the occurrence of irregularities. We have also recommended that, after every election that is conducted, the returning officer provide a report concerning the conduct of the ballot. That report will refer to a number of things including whether there were any rules which gave the returning officer some concern, and a recommendation that they be looked at with a view to amending or clarifying them. The report will also contain advice from the returning officer as to the number of voting papers sent out, the number of voting papers that went astray, and any other difficulties that he may have seen. We have recommended that there be an obligation imposed on industrial organisations to publish that report and, if they see fit, their response to that report so that their members are aware of just what occurred in the electoral process. We recommend that the filing of that report be the trigger for a three-month period within which a member must commence an application for an inquiry. We think the current period of 12 months is too long. It can cause administrative uncertainty and dislocation for a member to commence an inquiry right on the death knell of the 12-month period. We have also recommended that the returning officer undertake a sample check on membership rolls. We have not prescribed a percentage but have essentially left that to the discretion of the returning officer.
